name: 1,1'-thiocarbonyldi-2(1h)-pyridone
Reason: 1,1'-thiocarbonyldi-2(1H)-pyridone has a melting point that we can compare to benzene's melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings and a methoxy group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. The methoxy group introduces additional rigidity, which might raise the melting point by approximately +5 degrees Celsius. Additionally, the pyridine ring formation introduces additional rigidity, estimated at around +20 degrees Celsius. The carbonyl group introduces additional rigidity, estimated at around +30 degrees Celsius. The presence of two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion raises the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
